    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [1st Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



2.33 p.m.

    The Chairman: Will a Minister signify the recommendation of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara before the Committee proceeds with the consideration of the Main Estimates?

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Yes, I do.

    The Chairman: We are on the Main Estimates - Paper Cmd. 14 of 1963. For convenience, I intend taking the totals for each head as they appear in the last column of the abstract of estimated expenditure on pages 35 and 36 of the Paper.

    We are dealing now with the Heads of Expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper.

2.34 p.m.

Column: 863



    Head 1 -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 8.

    Sir, subhead 8 is a vote for two cars and, according to the notes here, these two cars are meant for replacement. I have gone through the Estimates of previous years and I find that for 1962 a vote of $12,350 was asked for a motorcar for replacement.

    I would like to know how many cars there are in Istana Negara and how old they are.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, the Yang di-Pertuan Negara inherited from the former Governor one Rolls Royce which is still in commission, one Humber Pullman which is now scrapped and replaced

Column: 864

by a Rover, one Austin and one Rover.

    The replacements are in respect of the Austin A60 and the Rover. The Austin is eight years old with a mileage of 130,000 miles and the Rover is 12 years old with a mileage of 76,000 miles.

    The Chairman: Does the Member for Cairnhill require a vote?

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: No, Sir. In view of the explanation given by the Prime Minister, may I beg leave to withdraw the amendment?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 10.

    Sir, this is a vote for Furniture and Furnishings of $20,800. Will the Prime Minister be good enough to inform this House in what way this vote will be spent? What is the type of additional furniture and the type of furnishings that will be required?

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker. Sir, there are five guest rooms at the Istana and, in view of the celebrations in August when we are anticipating a number of guests arriving for the occasion, it is deemed proper that these furnishings which have not been refurnished since 1945 should now be refurnished for the occasion.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: In view of the explanation given, may I beg leave to withdraw?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $392,230 for Head ordered Ito stand part of the Estimates.

Column: 864



    Head 2 -

    Mr S. T. Bani (Thomson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 2 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (1) of subhead 1.

    Sir, first of all, I must say how gratifying it is to note that the practice of having expatriate Chief Justices has finally given way to a new era in the judicial history of Singapore.

Column: 865



    I believe that no one would feel disgruntled at this basic change from our great misfortune to have had colonial Chief Justices whose contributions to the defence of the Empire are notorious in the annals of British colonial administration.

    The Chairman: Order. I must warn the hon. Member that we have a provision in the Order in Council which provides that the conduct of a Judge or Judges cannot he referred to except by a substantive motion on notice given by at least one-quarter of the number of Members in the Assembly. Therefore, there cannot be any comment on the conduct of Judges.

    Mr Bani: I am aware of the provision in the Order in Council, Mr Chairman, Sir, and I do not propose to touch on the conduct of the Chief Justice as such. I was merely making some general comment on the fact that today the high state of respectability of the Chief Justice of Singapore is held by a local man.

    Sir, to the extent that the present Chief Justice is a Malayan - more so a Singaporean - we are happy. It is appropriate though that we reflect this appointment in the perspective of an independent Judiciary on which I propose to elaborate under my next amendment.

    Sir, I am sorry to say that the appointment of Justice Wee Chong Jin as the Chief Justice has not created the jubilation that it should have, if not for anything else then at least for the fact that it is the first local appointment. Sir, the discontent over this appointment, I am sure, is known to many. It is unlikely that Members of this House are not aware of this.

    It is not for me to talk of the competence or otherwise of Justice Wee, but what is paramount is to stress the need for a non-political approach by the Government to the Judiciary.

    Sir, it is an open secret today that the appointment of Justice Wee is regarded as a political appointment. Sir, having witnessed the conduct of the P.A.P. Government in the last four years, it is not difficult to understand the legitimate apprehension that the P.A.P. is capable

Column: 866

of making the law courts P.A.P. law courts. It is regrettable that the P.A.P. persists in converting State institutions into P.A.P. organs. Sir, the people cannot place trust on justice if political colouring is introduced into the administration of justice. It is needless for me to say that it will be a sad day for Singapore if British colonial Chief Justices are to be replaced by P.A.P. Chief Justices.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, I do not wish to demean the position of the Chief Justice by entering into a debate on this matter.

    If the Member for Thomson is so inclined as to pursue this point and I think having made this point in passing, I suggest that he pursue it. Then I am quite prepared to have the matter investigated.

    Under the Constitution, before the appointment is made by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, the Prime Minister who has to give the advice is obliged to con-suit the retiring Chief Justice, which I did. I think the retiring Chief Justice deemed it fit and proper before he left the country to indicate what he thought of the advice he gave me. I also took advice from all members of the Bar Committee. Amongst the members I consulted was the Member for Farrer Park. I do not wish any justification for the choice made, which I can in good conscience say was the best that any Prime Minister in my position could have done. The fact that the Member for Thomson should have chosen in a sly way to try somehow to bring discredit to an institution of some importance in a democratic State without really wishing to pursue the point is, I think, a sad reflection on the standards of the Opposition. Men who have not got the courage to pursue their allegations publicly should desist from making sly and oblique references.

    Mr Bani: I merely wish to say this. As I did explain, I was not making any reference to the conduct of Justice Wee as such. I was merely airing a grievance over the appointment ---

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Whose grievance?

Column: 867



    Mr Bani: --- which I think is widely known and which I am quite sure the Prime Minister is aware of.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): I am astounded to hear the grievance. The Member for Thomson may not know that, in fact, the Bar Committee was unanimous that this was a fit and proper choice. To begin with, Mr Justice Wee was already on the Bench when this Government took office.

2.45 p.m.

    There was a choice of elevating one of the members of the Bench or seeking someone from the Bar. The two choices were both exhaustively surveyed and resurveyed. All I can say is I am grateful to the members of the Bar Committee and several leading members of the Bar of the advice they gave. I am sure that in doe course everybody will realise the wisdom of the appointment.

    The Chairman: Does the Member for Thomson require a vote?

    Mr Bani: Yes.

    Question on the amendment put, and negatived.

    Mr Bani: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 2 be reduced by $100.

    Sir, the manner of appointment of Judges and magistrates today in Singapore dues not inspire ---

    The Prime Minister rose ---

    The Chairman: On a point of order?

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): On a point of order. I think before the Member for Thomson pursues further and casts a general slur on the Judiciary, I must bring to his attention first the fact that he is casting an aspersion on a small group of men. The law has it that if you cast an aspersion on a group of men so small - all are identifiable - then you do so at your own peril. And I say that if a Member commits a breach of privilege in this Chamber, using the privilege of this Chamber to cast aspersions on the conduct of Judges, then he must be prepared

Column: 868

to face the consequences. It might interest him to know that under the Constitution to the Judges are appointed by a commission consisting of the Chief Justice and his brother Judges, including the State Advocate-General.

    The Chairman: I think, at the moment, the Member for Thomson is in order as he is just attacking the method of appointment. The method of appointment has already been indicated by the Prime Minister and is provided for in the Order in Council.

    Mr Bani: That is quite so, Mr Chairman, and under this amendment, I merely wish to discuss the manner of appointment of Judges to the lower courts. Sir, I would say that the ---

    The Prime Minister rose ---

    The Chairman: Is it a point of order again?

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): It is a point of order. He is going to attack the manner of appointment to the lower courts and I suggest he move under a different subhead. This deals with Puisne Judges.

    The Chairman: It is under Judicial.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): I thought he was moving under subhead 1.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Wake up! Do not sleep.

    The Chairman: Order. The amendment is in regard to the whole of Head 2

    Mr Bani: I can understand the anxiety of the Prime Minister ---

    The Prime Minister: There is no anxiety.

    Mr Bani: I can only tell him to contain himself and reply at the time when he will definitely be allowed to reply.

    Sir, I was saying that the manner of appointment of Judges and magistrates does not inspire public confidence ---

    The Prime Minister: You mean your confidence?

    Mr Bani: --- in the administration of justice. Now, this is especially so in present day Singapore with the P.A.P.

Column: 869

Government whose manipulation of State organs for political purposes is unprecedented. Sir, under the Constitution, the powers to appoint, promote or transfer district judges and magistrates is vested in the Legal Service Commission under section 93 of the Constitution, page 42. The Legal Service Commission consists of:

    (a) the Chief Justice;

    (b) the Chairman of the Public Service Commission;

    (c) a Judge of the Supreme Court nominated generally or specially by the Chief Justice;

    (d) the State Advocate-General; and

    (e) not more than two members of the Public Service Commission nominated generally or specially by the Chairman.

    Sir, first of all, the Chief Justice is appointed by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara in accordance with the advice of the Prime Minister. For practical purposes, it means that he must be a man of the Prime Minister's choice; secondly, the Chairman of the Public Service Commission is also in the same manner appointed by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara in accordance with the advice of the Prime Minister; thirdly, the State Advocate-General is also appointed in the same manner. The remaining members, as has been pointed out, are appointed by the Chief Justice and the Chairman of the Public Service Commission.

    Sir, the Legal Service Commission as constituted, as has been explained, is a body which has the authority for the appointment, promotion or transfer of all district judges and magistrates. That is the first point that I wish to make in respect of the manner of appointment of Judges and magistrates.

    The second point, Sir, is the current practice in the appointment and transfer of district court judges and magistrates. Art officer who is a magistrate today can be transferred tomorrow to become a Deputy Public Prosecutor and vice versa. There are many examples: one outstanding example is Mr Francis Seow Tiang Siew. He was a D.P.P. at one Time: then he was transferred to be

Column: 870

a district court judge for some months and now, Sir, he is transferred once again to he a D.P.P. Incidentally, Mr Speaker, Sir, Mr Francis Seow is a gold medallist, though not in the Olympics, but in the legal service for having run the race well on behalf of the P.A.P. He was awarded the ---

    The Chairman: Order. There the Member is treading on very dangerous ground. He is now reflecting indirectly on the conduct of a legal officer. He must not do that.

    Mr Bani: All I wanted to point out was that he was awarded the Public Administration Medal - Pingat Pentadbiran ---

    The Chairman: Order. Those medals are awarded for conduct and therefore there is an indirect reflection on the officer's conduct. That must not be done in this Chamber.

    Mr Bani: Very well, Mr Speaker, Sir, that was just one example. Then there are many other examples, and I do not propose to go into them now. But if the Government wants, I am quite prepared to list out a few more examples later on.

    Sir, the practical effect of all this is that a district judge, before whom the Solicitor-General appears and whose conduct is subject to the authority of the Judge, can one day be transferred and he expected to work under the Solicitor-General. Again. Sir, the other way round. A Deputy Public Prosecutor, who works under the Solicitor-General and takes instructions from him today, may be transferred tomorrow to become a district judge before whom the Solicitor-General will have to appear. I am quite sure the Government Members will agree that there are very illustrious examples of this to be quoted. It is hardly necessary for me to say that this practice puts the district judge or a magistrate in an invidious position in the administration of justice, particularly too, when the Solicitor-General himself appears in the courts. The least I can say is that this practice is scandalous. Perhaps you will recall that there was a case of a district judge who was transferred soon after a particular case in which six trade

Column: 871

unionists were involved. Sir, some Members of this House have suggested on a previous occasion that an independent Judiciary is one of the pillars of democracy. Sir, there is no doubt that this is a laudable acclamation, though it is regrettable that it came from some people who merely pay lip service to democratic practices. The basis of my argument is not democracy or what have we. There is no democracy in Singapore, and Singapore is hardly a democracy. Therefore, Sir, it would be futile to talk about pillars of democracy. I hope that Members of this House - particularly those self-acclaimed champions of democracy sitting across the Floor - will forgive me if I put aside democracies and pillars of democracies and talk of hard reality.

    Sir, the administration of justice, in our view, is the essence of a civilised human society. The independence of the Judiciary is a fundamental pre-requisite for the administration of justice, as it should be. Justice in one form or another has been the crux of struggle in human society. However, unfortunately, institutions for the administration of justice have been more often than not instruments of oppression in the hands of the ruling class. Today, in Singapore, the P.A.P. takes honours for having excelled in the use of State organs for repression and oppression.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, but for the aspersions that have been cast not upon me, but upon the Chief Justice, the State Advocate-General, the Chairman of the P.S.C. and a whole host of other appointments made by me, including the Speaker of this Chamber, I would have deemed the remarks made by the Member for Thomson beneath comment.

    It is in the nature of things that somebody has to make an appointment and in the new Constitution which came into operation in 1959. I inherited in my office the powers of a Governor, the Chief Secretary and the Mayor. If these powers, Mr Speaker, Sir, are wrongly used, then the institutions of the State will disintegrate. I am proud to say that at least as a result of the appointments made, housing has succeeded, the Polytechnic

Column: 872

is expanding, the Public Utilities Board is well on its way to being established, and a whole host of statutory corporations, including the Singapore Harbour Board, are functioning efficiently, discharging their duties to the community. But to suggest, as the Member for Thomson suggests, that one makes political appointments for the purposes of having yes men is a proposition so absurd and so stupid that if ever he got endowed with these powers and uses them in the way he believes I have used them, then the State would collapse ---

    An hon. Member: It is collapsing.

    The Prime Minister: With one flat going up every 45 minutes, with more roads built than ever in four years, than ever in the history of Singapore, with more street lights going up than ever before, with more kampongs in receipt of electricity than ever before, with more standpipes in all the rural areas than ever in the history of Singapore - [Interruption]. These things cannot be done in a matter of months. These are plans formulated in 1959 and 1960, when the unpleasant decisions had to be made to up the taxes, to put on the economy measures, in order to produce results in 1961, 1962 and now 1963. If only the Member for Thomson had more moral fibre, he would have stood up to the Communists at the unpopular moments that we went through and he would have seen sunshine at the end of it all. Instead of that, they switched sides and now they found out that it was the wrong side. I suggest to the Member for Thomson seriously to consider whether he is wise in his own interest to make these suggestions. Mr Francis Scow is one of the outstanding officers in the State Advocate-General's Department, and the State Advocate-General, I am proud to say, recommended him for a citation, together with other officers.

3.00 p.m.

    A D.P.P. prosecuting or a Solicitor-General prosecuting before a district court is no unusual business. I defended certain friends of the Member for Thomson before the District Judge with the Solicitor-General then prosecuting, Mr Shanks. The District Judge acquitted

Column: 873

and he is now sitting as a Puisne Judge. As District Judge, Mr Francis Seow sentenced Mr Bani's close associate and stooge, Mr Foo, in the Business Houses Employees Union, to nine months for putting lighted cigarettes on the back of non-striking workers in a cowardly and dastardly manner. They appealed. The Chief Justice, who is not my appointment - it was an appointment by a former Governor - Sir Alan Rose, confirmed the sentence, and he served his nine months. I hope he is the wiser for it; for if there is any more such foolishness of brutality and bullying next time, he will find that the first offence is taken into consideration when the second conviction is considered.

    Political appointments? District Judge? Mr Choor Singh was there for years before the P.A.P. Mr Jamit Singh got a full and proper trial. I will not say whether he got his deserts. It is a matter for the Court of Appeal to decide. Everybody heard every scrap of evidence, every lie that went on in the court for a full 2½ months. Is the Member for Thomson suggesting that this Government should allow prosecutions to fail through lack of police investigations?

    The Chairman: Order. I think the Prime Minister is going a bit wide of the subject. Can he come back to "appointments"?

    The Prime Minister: Appointments. There is no new appointment that I know of, no important new appointments anywhere. The Judges are the same. One Puisne Judge becomes the Chief Justice. The Solicitor-General has become a Puisne Judge. The Registrar of the Supreme Court has gone and become the Acting Solicitor-General. The No. 2 District Judge has become the No. 1 District Judge. These were appointments we inherited. And so it went on.

    I suggest to the Member for Thomson that he and his friends should really examine their own heads. They always do this, Mr Speaker, Sir: first, they say they are going to win the referendum. Right on the very eve ---

    The Chairman: Order. I hope the Prime Minister is not opening a debate

Column: 874

on that. He can mention that only in passing.

    The Prime Minister: To prove a point. Then when they lost, they said it was a fraud, phoney and cheap. We said petition. They did not petition. They have got the right to petition. Three M.P.s came. They welcomed them. One thousand people went to the Airport. The Member for Queenstown insisted that he had invited the three M.P.s. He said so. He was proud that he had invited them.

    The Chairman: Order. Can the Prime Minister explain how that arises from this debate?

    The Prime Minister: This is the point. They insisted that they address the meeting. Then when the verdict of the three M.P.s was against him, he whereupon denounced all three and said they had been taken on a conducted tour and they were gullible old gentlemen. Similarly with the Courts. We know that Members on the other side, on a certain day not so very long ago, came with other gentlemen to look for me. I do not know how lucky they were that I was not in. I do not know whether they were aware that certain definite security arrangements were made when the Cabinet is in session, as we have no intention to be wiped out like the Burmese Cabinet. It was well that we were not in session, and therefore the police were forbearing in extremis.

    The Chairman: Order. I do not think that those remarks are proper because the case is sub judice. I do not think any reference should be made to it.

    The Prime Minister: Indeed, Mr Speaker, Sir,I just wish to point this out, that now having felt the rigours of the law run their course in the case of Mr Foo and the case of Mr Jamit Singh, they wish to prepare the ground for a denunciation of the whole Judiciary. Why? Because their conduct will now be put to serious scrutiny. It is not my fault, Mr Speaker, Sir, that they choose to do mad things; that they choose to do things of their own volition. But I say this. Say these things here and breach privilege, and they face

Column: 875

the consequences. Say these things outside and I have not the slightest doubt that the gentlemen referred to will defend themselves. If the Member for Thomson is at all serious about these allegations, I say make these suggestions outside, because I really do not want to tight their battle. It makes it difficult for me. These are their own battles. Any aspersions he likes to cast on them outside, they have their remedies. I wish the Member for Thomson well.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not rise to participate in the debate between the Prime Minister and the Member for Thomson. But I cannot allow the claim of the Prime Minister pass unchallenged. He claims that the P.A.P. has put up more stand-pipes. I say all that is nothing but a cruel joke. More stand-pipes without water? More stand-pipes for what? He claims that more houses are being built. Yet there are 4,000 vacant houses not yet occupied. Would it not be wiser to see that the 4,000 units built by the Housing and Development Board are occupied?

    The Chairman: Order. That is exactly what I fear - a debate completely away from what we are in fact debating. Perhaps the hon. Member for Cairnhill will raise those points again when we come to the proper Ministry.

    Mr Bani: The Prime Minister, to escape the basic issue, goes around ---

    The Prime Minister: Repeat these things outside.

    The Chairman: Order.

    Mr Bani: --- beating about the bush. Sir, he always misses the point. We realise that the Prime Minister has acted within the law, within the powers vested upon him by virtue of the fact that he is the Prime Minister of the State of Singapore. I am not suggesting that he has done anything illegal or ultra vires the Constitution. I was saying that it is undesirable to have a system of appointments and transfers of district judges and magistrates whereby a person who is a magistrate today can be transferred

Column: 876

to become a Deputy Public Prosecutor tomorrow. Sir, we realise that in these transfers the Legal Service Commission is acting according to the rules. But is it desirable? That is our basic point', and we think, if the public and those who are accused are to be expected to have confidence in the courts and in the administration of justice, then such undesirable practices must not be allowed to continue. I was not casting aspersions on officers in the legal service. My grouse is against this basic practice ---

    The Prime Minister: You are back-pedalling.

    Mr Bani: --- which the Government apparently is not doing anything to rectify. Sir, if I may just say this before I sit down, because the Prime Minister with a lot of vigour has suggested that so many thousands of stand-pipes and housing flats and so on have been built ---

    The Chairman: Order. I have stopped the Member for Cairnhill from raising that point. I do not want a debate on stand-pipes or roads or any housing. That debate can arise when we come to the Ministry of National Development.

    Mr Bani: All that I wanted to say was - because this was said 1w the Prime Minister - in the context whether the State organs are disintegrating. Sir, I share his views that the State organs must not disintegrate. That is precisely why we are trying to tell the Government, "Do not utilise State organs. Do not make it a farce by turning each and every single State organ into a P.A.P. organ." [Interruption].

    The Chairman: Order. I am trying to channel the debate now. Criticism of the Prime Minister as to the state of State organs and as to appointments in these other State organs, I think, can come when we deal with the Prime Minister's Ministry.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Mr Speaker, Sir, I must congratulate the Prime Minister on his clever distortion of fact. I have already said that the P.A.P. excels only in one department, and that is the department of distortions and sell-outs.

Column: 877



    The Prime Minister: That is two already. You cannot even count!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: He has just said a little while back that I insisted that I invited the three M.P.s. I never did say that. But I am telling the Prime Minister once more, in case he should forget, that it was as a result of my challenge to the M.P.s that they came along to Singapore to see for themselves.

    The Prime Minister: And spend so much time and effort.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I did not denounce them after they had so-called passed judgment on us. In fact, when I made my speech in the Happy World Stadium, I had already given them my speech telling them that I was answering every point raised by Mr Bottomley. So what is all this about our denouncing the three M.P.s? We did not denounce them. We never expected too much from them. We knew what to expect from M.P.s in the Labour Party of Britain who hold views not very different from those held by Conservatives ---

    The Chairman: Order. I think the Member for Queenstown has made his point up to now, and I am sure there will be other opportunities in the Committee of Supply for the hon. Member to expand on it. I will not allow any debate on that particular aspect.

    The Prime Minister: I just wish to reply to the Member for Thomson on the system of transfers. I can only tell him that the only mitigation I can find for him is that probably he is ignorant of the system of law that is applied in this country, and indeed that applies in all other countries where members of the Bar and the Bench are small in number.

    Sir, it is a pity that the Member for Anson is not here, because I think on an occasion like this he serves a useful purpose, because I use him as a sounding board for concessions and admissions. All over the British Commonwealth, this system prevails. Before a man can ever become a Judge of the High court, he should have, in his career, acquired a varied experience as prosecutor, as counsel for the defendant and the plaintiff,

Column: 878

adviser, draftsman, magistrate, Registrar, and Official Assignee. In other parts of the world, they have recruited their puisne judges from the Bar. Different systems prevail.
